description.narrative: Cities Alliance is a global collaboration between most of the relevant stakeholders within urban development such as UN-Habitat, World Bank, UCLG and SDI. The main activities are country and regional programmes, catalytic (small project) fund, knowledge and learning, and communication and advocacy. Its focus is on, among other, poor people, Sub-sahara Africa and secondary cities.

Insats WB TF-fond - Kan därför stängas först 170701. Cities Alliance är en global sammanslutning av de flesta relevanta aktörerna inom urban utveckling såsom tex UN-Habitat, Världsbanken, UCLG och SDI. Huvudaktiviteterna består av land och regionala program, katalytiska fonden, kunskapsutveckling samt kommunikation och lobbying. Fokus fattiga människor, Afrika söder Sahara, sekondära städer.

participating-org.narrative: UNOPS/United Nations Office for Project Services

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The expected long-term outcome of the Cities Alliance is "Cities increasingly characterized by effective local government, active citizenship and delivering improved and responsive services to the urban poor". The over-arching objectives of Cities Alliance is: a) To strenghten and promote the role of cities in poverty reduction, and in sustainable development; b) To capture and strenghten the synergies between and among members and partners; and c) To improve the quality of urban development cooperation and lending.
The work of the CA is generally according to plan and to the indended outcome.
The main focus during 2016 had been on closing the Future Africa project and most of its country programmes (five or seven); convening the first Cities Alliance assembly and electing a new set of persons/organisations in key positions; its active participation in the critical Third United Nations Conference on Housing and Sustainable Urban Development (Habitat III) conference as well as finalising the administrative reforms that were a consequence from the relocation from World Bank to UNOPS.
The following selected results from 2016 indicate progress towards the intended outcome:
-There are now active national urban fora formulating national responses to rapid urbanisation in all the five country programmes that was closed in 2016 (Uganda, Ghana, Burkina Faso, Mocambique and Vietnam). In most or all of these countries, these types of fora for all relevant stakeholders to meed regularly to discuss urbanisation have not existed before. In all the countries, an evaluation showed that 100 percent of the stakeholders acknowledged that Cities Alliance helped to establish a platform for partnership. -The drafting of municipal development strategies and enumerations of urban poor settlements in 14 secondary cities in Uganda. In these cities, local governments have been released land for the urban poor. -The results framework shows that, in slums and/or low income areas, access to potable water is now 74% (compared to target of 66%) and access to regular electricity is now 71% (target 61%) which is significantly higher than the baseline (water 63%/electricity 58%) in the five country programmes that are now closed.
It should be noted that progress against expected results at the tier I and II level has been mixed. It has even not been possible to use some of the originally expected indicator as the required data is missing at the national and local level. However, it is Sida's assessment that the indicators at tier I and tier II-level are not as important in this context as a rather small organisation such as Cities Alliance can hardly be responsible for developments at the larger level in cities and countries. Thus, it is most important to assess what is happening at tier II and tier IV-level which is related to what Cities Alliance or its members are expected to achieve.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
